sn35.17:1.1: “Monks, if there were no gratification in the seer, sentient beings wouldn’t be aroused by it.
sn35.17:1.2: But since there is gratification in the seer, sentient beings are aroused by it.
sn35.17:1.3: If the seer had no drawback, sentient beings wouldn’t grow disillusioned with it.
sn35.17:1.4: But since the seer has a drawback, sentient beings do grow disillusioned with it.
sn35.17:1.5: If there were no escape from the seer, sentient beings wouldn’t escape from it.
sn35.17:1.6: But since there is an escape from the seer, sentient beings do escape from it.
sn35.17:1.7: If there were no gratification in the hearer …
sn35.17:1.16: the thinker, sentient beings wouldn’t be aroused by it.
sn35.17:1.17: But since there is gratification in the thinker, sentient beings are aroused by it.
sn35.17:1.18: If the thinker had no drawback, sentient beings wouldn’t grow disillusioned with it.
sn35.17:1.19: But since the thinker has a drawback, sentient beings do grow disillusioned with it.
sn35.17:1.20: If there were no escape from the thinker, sentient beings wouldn’t escape from it.
sn35.17:1.21: But since there is an escape from the thinker, sentient beings do escape from it.
sn35.17:2.1: As long as sentient beings don’t truly understand these six interior sense fields’ gratification, drawback, and escape for what they are, they haven’t escaped from this world—with its gods, Māras, and Brahmās, this population with its ascetics and brahmins, its gods and humans—and they don’t live detached, liberated, with a mind free of limits.
sn35.17:2.2: But when sentient beings truly understand these six interior sense fields’ gratification, drawback, and escape for what they are, they’ve escaped from this world—with its gods, Māras, and Brahmās, this population with its ascetics and brahmins, its gods and humans—and they live detached, liberated, with a mind free of limits.”
